properties.areaDesc: Northern Blue Mountains of Oregon; Foothills of the Northern Blue Mountains of Oregon; Grande Ronde Valley; Foothills of the Blue Mountains of Washington; East Slopes of the Washington Cascades; Northwest Blue Mountains; Kittitas Valley; Yakima Valley
properties.headline: Hydrologic Outlook issued February 4 at 11:08AM PST by NWS Pendleton OR
properties.description:
Several weather systems will be moving through the Pacific
Northwest this week and will bring periods of moderate to heavy
rain Wednesday through Friday. Highest rainfall amounts will be
over the Washington Cascades with 2 to 4 inches likely with the
northeast Oregon and southeast Washington mountains expected to
receive 1 to 3 inches.

Snow levels will be rising to around 6000 feet on Wednesday and
remain at this level through Thursday and then decrease on Friday
to around 3000 feet in the Washington Cascades and 4000 feet for
the Blue Mountains.

The combination of rain and snowmelt will increase flows on
rivers, creeks, and streams draining the east slopes of the
Washington Cascades as well as the Blue Mountains of Washington
and Oregon.

The strongest rises will be seen on Thursday and Friday with most
creeks, streams and rivers cresting late Friday and early
Saturday.

At this time, no widespread flooding is expected on the large rivers,
but minor flood impacts may be seen in the headwaters of the
Yakima River northwest of Cle Elum.

If you live along a creek, stream or river, be aware of the
changing conditions and continue to monitor weather and
stream flow forecasts.

NWSheadline: RAIN AND SNOWMELT WILL CAUSE SIGNIFICANT RISES ON RIVERS AND STREAMS THURSDAY AND FRIDAY
